title: Tinnitus and Hearing Loss C&P Exam Preparation Guide

why_common.explanation: Tinnitus (ringing in the ears) and hearing loss are among the most claimed disabilities by veterans—and for good reason. Military service often means exposure to loud noise.
why_common.note: Even a single loud blast can cause permanent hearing damage. Years of exposure without proper protection makes these conditions almost inevitable for many veterans.

content.how_exam_works: Unlike other C&P exams, hearing exams are highly objective. You'll sit in a soundproof booth, wear headphones, and listen for tones. A machine measures exactly what you can and cannot hear. There's no physical manipulation, no pain, and no subjective interpretation.

rating_info.hearing_loss: Your rating (0% to 100%) is based on a mathematical formula using pure tone threshold averages (how loud sounds must be for you to hear them) and speech recognition scores (how well you understand spoken words).
rating_info.tinnitus: The maximum rating is 10%—regardless of severity. However, tinnitus is one of the easiest conditions to service-connect because it's subjective (only you can hear it). If you had noise exposure in service and now have ringing in your ears, you'll likely be granted service connection.
rating_info.important_note: Even a 10% tinnitus rating adds to your combined rating and can help you reach higher compensation brackets.

pure_tone_audiometry.description: You'll hear a series of beeps (tones) at different frequencies and volumes.
pure_tone_audiometry.measurement: Volume measured in decibels (dB)—higher numbers mean louder sounds needed
pure_tone_audiometry.result: The softest sound you can hear at each frequency is recorded. These numbers are averaged to calculate your 'pure tone threshold average.'

speech_recognition.description: You'll hear recorded words through headphones and repeat them back. This measures how well you understand speech, not just hear sounds.
speech_recognition.example_scores: Right ear: 92% speech recognition, Left ear: 76% speech recognition

tinnitus_evaluation.description: Tinnitus is subjective—only you can hear it. The examiner documents:
factors_documented: Frequency: Is it constant (24/7) or intermittent (comes and goes)?
Character: Ringing, buzzing, hissing, roaring, clicking?
Location: One ear, both ears, or inside your head?
Severity: How much does it affect your life?

types.persistent: Present all or most of the time

tinnitus_evaluation.note: Both qualify for the 10% rating if service-connected.

procedure_steps.name: Otoscope Exam
procedure_steps.description: The examiner looks in your ears with a lighted scope to check for wax buildup, infections, or damage. This takes about 30 seconds per ear.

procedure_steps.name: Enter the Booth
procedure_steps.description: You'll sit in a small, soundproof booth. It's quiet inside—that's intentional. The door closes to block outside noise.

procedure_steps.name: Headphones On
procedure_steps.description: You'll wear headphones. The examiner controls the test from outside the booth and can see you through a window.

procedure_steps.name: Pure Tone Test
procedure_steps.description: You'll hear beeps (tones) at different pitches and volumes. Raise your hand OR press a button when you hear a tone. The tones start loud and get softer until you can't hear them. Each ear is tested separately.

procedure_steps.name: Speech Recognition Test
procedure_steps.description: You'll hear recorded words through the headphones. Repeat each word out loud exactly as you hear it. Some words will be easy; others may be hard to understand. Don't guess—say what you actually hear.

what_to_expect.note: You may hear nothing at some frequencies (that's normal for hearing loss)

questions: When did you first notice hearing loss or tinnitus?
Was there a specific event (explosion, gunfire, aircraft)?
What was your military job? What noise were you exposed to?
Do you have ringing in your ears? How often?
Is it constant or does it come and go?
What does it sound like (ringing, buzzing, hissing)?
Does it affect your concentration at work?
Do you have trouble hearing conversations?
Do you need the TV or radio turned up loud?
Have you had ear infections or surgeries?
Have you had any ear injuries?
Do you have any other ear conditions?

document_noise_exposure.instruction: Write down every type of loud noise you experienced in service:

review_service_records: Look for audiograms from entrance and exit physicals
Note any hearing conservation program records

details_to_note: Frequency: Constant? Or how many times per day/week?
Sound type: Ringing, buzzing, hissing, whooshing, roaring?
Location: Left ear, right ear, both, or center of head?
Volume: Soft background noise or loud and intrusive?
Impact: Sleep problems, concentration issues, mood effects?

document_hearing_loss: Situations where you struggle to hear
Do people complain you don't hear them?
Do you ask people to repeat themselves often?

protect_hearing: Avoid loud environments (concerts, power tools, loud music)
Don't use earplugs during the exam (you need to hear the tones)

golden_rule.title: The Golden Rule: Don't Guess
golden_rule.instruction: During the hearing test, only raise your hand when you actually hear a tone. This is critical.
do: Wait until you're certain you hear something
Raise your hand even for very faint tones
Accept that you may hear nothing at some frequencies
dont: Guess when you think a tone should come
Raise your hand because you 'might' have heard something
Try to perform better than you actually can
golden_rule.why_it_matters: If you guess correctly, your hearing appears better than it is. The test measures your true hearing ability—let it.

example_statements: I hear constant ringing in both ears, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week
The buzzing is loud enough that it interferes with conversations
I can't fall asleep without a fan or white noise because the ringing is so loud in silence
I have trouble concentrating at work because of the ringing
The tinnitus makes me irritable and affects my mood

explain_impact.instruction: Don't just describe symptoms—explain how they affect your life:
examples: I have to ask my wife to repeat herself multiple times
I can't hear my grandchildren when they talk to me
I've avoided social situations because I can't follow conversations
I haven't slept through the night in years because of the ringing

mistakes.description: This is the #1 mistake. Veterans sometimes raise their hand when they think a tone 'should' be playing. Every false positive makes your hearing appear better than it is.
mistakes.fix: Only respond when you're certain. It's okay to miss tones—that's what hearing loss looks like on a test.

mistakes.description: Many veterans have lived with ringing for so long they consider it 'normal.' Don't minimize it.
mistakes.wrong: It's just a little ringing, I'm used to it
mistakes.right: I have constant ringing that affects my sleep and concentration

mistakes.description: The examiner can measure your hearing, but they can't know how it affects your life unless you tell them. Explain the real-world consequences.

mistakes.mistake: Assuming the Examiner Knows Your Job
mistakes.description: Don't assume the examiner understands that your MOS involved noise exposure. Explain it: 'I was an artillery gunner—I fired howitzers daily for 3 years' or 'I worked on the flight deck of an aircraft carrier.'
If your service records don't clearly show noise exposure, your own statement matters. Write it down before the exam.

request_results.instruction: You can get a copy of your audiogram:
request_results.note: Review the numbers. If they don't match your experience, you may have grounds to challenge.

items: Whether the booth was truly quiet
Whether the equipment seemed to work properly
What you told the examiner about tinnitus impact

red_flags: The booth wasn't soundproof (you heard outside noise)
Examiner didn't ask about tinnitus impact on daily life
Examiner didn't take a noise exposure history
content.timeline: Rating decisions typically arrive 60-90 days after your exam. Hearing claims are often processed faster because the results are objective.

closing_message.text: Your hearing damage happened in service to your country. Whether it's the constant ringing that keeps you awake or the conversations you can no longer follow, these are real injuries that deserve recognition.
closing_message.encouragement: Be honest. Don't guess. Let the test show your true hearing—and make sure the examiner understands how it affects your life.

preparation_checklist.task: Document all military noise exposure events (weapons, vehicles, aircraft, combat)
Review service records for entrance/exit audiograms and MOS documentation
Write detailed tinnitus description (frequency, sound type, location, volume)
Document tinnitus impact on sleep, concentration, work, and mood
List situations where hearing loss affects daily life (conversations, TV volume, etc.)
Confirm exam date, time, and location
Avoid loud noise exposure (concerts, power tools, loud music)
Get normal sleep the night before
Bring written notes about noise exposure history and tinnitus symptoms
Remember: Only raise hand when you ACTUALLY hear a tone—don't guess

key_facts.tinnitus_service_connection: Relatively easy to establish with noise exposure history
key_facts.hearing_loss_rating_basis: Pure tone threshold averages + speech recognition scores
